coreCitation.title: American Community Survey Statistical Tables
coreCitation.fullNotes:
- The American Community Survey (ACS) is a demographic data collection effort that is continuously being carried out by the U.S. Census Bureau
		- Results of the survey are released every year by the U.S. Census Bureau
		- Results are made available at different time scales: 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year estimates
		- Instead of sharing personal information about each individual who responds, the U.S. Census Bureau **aggregates** survey responses to broader geographic units, in order to protect individual's privacy
		- You can download these statistical tables which are aggregated to different geographic scales, including: states, counties, zip codes, tracts and block groups
		- The ACS survey results are maintained in massive databases hosted by the U.S. Census Bureau and other authorized data providers
		- To download the data, you will need to first decide which time period, geographic unit, and statistical theme you wish to work with
		- Once you know these filters, you can use an extract tool to download the data you want, such as [data.census.gov](https://data.census.gov/cedsci/), or the more user and GIS-friendly [National Historic GIS (NHGIS)](https://www.nhgis.org/)
coreCitation.briefGenealogy: A common process is to join statistical demographic data from the American Community Survey or decennial census with census shape data like tracts, counties or states.
coreCitation.accessCondition: This data is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on access.

temporal.temporalNotes: Census data, while dating back to the 1790s, was collected in slightly different ways for every census year. This means that the way census geographies and demographic categories are available is subject to nuance, depending on which year you are looking for. NHGIS.org has this handy documentation that includes data availability tables for any given census year: https://nhgis.org/user-resources/data-availability

documentation.title: ACS Summary File Handbook: What Data Users Need to Know
American Community Survey (ACS) Design and Methodology

tutorials.title: Working with NHGIS and Joins
tutorials.author: Creighton University Digital Humanities
tutorials.notes: Learn how to join census data with demographic data in QGIS

representation.healthCheckQualifier: There is strong documentation about the process by which survey questions were initially designed, how stakeholders were involved, and the process by which new questions are added. There could be healthier context made available for continuous efforts to ensure adequate representation in the survey design and collection process.

publicResponsibility.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation is strong for issues related to technical methodology for geographic aggregation and anonymization. It discusses why the data is beneficial to society. There could be healthier context made available for known privacy issues and the steps taken to ensure all participants understand how their data will be used. The documentation could also state more clearly how the data should and should not be used, with clear remarks about known limitations.

historicContext.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation does not reflect on the ways the data program is at risk for repeating past harms. It does not describe the ways in which U.S. census data collection has considered its relationship and contribution to systemic injustice.

potentialImpact.healthCheckQualifier: There is healthy documentation about potential positive impact and future funding dependent on this data program. There is not very much easily discoverable documentation about potential negative impact, especially if there are existing factors which should be flagged to avoid harm.

maintenance.maintenanceFrequency: These datasets are added to NHGIS within four - six weeks of the official census release.
